channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Euro 2020: Croatia 3-1 Scotland - Steve Clarke's side undone at Hampden
item.description: Scotland's dream of making history by progressing at Euro 2020 came to a sobering end with a heartbreaking defeat to Croatia at Hampden.

item.title: England 1-0 Czech Republic: Raheem Sterling strike ensures Three Lions win group
item.description: Raheem Sterling's second goal of Euro 2020 sees England beat the Czech Republic to win Group D and set up a last-16 tie against France, Germany, Portugal or Hungary at Wembley.

item.title: Scotland aiming to lift all Covid restrictions by 9 August
item.description: The current rules will remain in place until 19 July - with the aim of lifting remaining restrictions in August.

item.title: Dominic Cummings tried to bypass rules over £530k grant, emails suggest
item.description: The PM's ex-top aide told officials to "immediately" issue a £530,000 grant with "no procurement".

item.title: Covid-19: Aim for double-jabbed arrivals to avoid quarantine - Hancock
item.description: Ministers are "working on" plans for quarantine-free travel from amber list countries if vaccinated.

item.title: Tinder boss says Covid changed how we swipe right
item.description: "They want to slow things down and get to know people first a lot more before they decide to match."

item.title: Having coil fitted should not hurt, say experts
item.description: But they say pain relief should be part of the discussion when fitting this type of contraceptive.

item.title: Angela Merkel receives Moderna as second jab after AstraZeneca shot
item.description: Experts believe mixed dosing of Covid vaccines could be a good idea but it's too early to say for sure.

item.title: Higher ethnic minority maternity risk examined
item.description: Maternity services are failing women belonging to ethnic minorities, the charity investigating says.

item.title: Cricketer hits huge six through his own car window
item.description: Asif Ali smashed the boundary - and his car's back window - during a cup match.

item.title: Turkmenistan's capital tops list of most expensive cities for expats
item.description: The annual report ranks 209 cities based on the cost of expenses such as housing, transport and food.

item.title: Nicholas Watt: Second man charged after BBC reporter chased
item.description: Footage showed Newsnight political editor Nicholas Watt being taunted near Downing Street.

item.title: Cardboard 'in people's garages causing shortage'
item.description: Packaging firm DS Smith is working with local councils to increase the amount of cardboard for recycling.

item.title: Windrush Day: 'Windrush is the big thing in the black community'
item.description: Avril Nanton and Jody Burton have released a book looking at London's black history.

item.title: Bobby Zamora scores spectacular goal for friend's team in Colchester
item.description: The ex-Premier League player was spotted playing for a friend's team in Colchester

item.title: Wymondham mechanic finds python under bonnet during MOT
item.description: The snake named Gav, which belongs to the vehicle's owners, had been missing for two weeks.

item.title: Wally the Walrus takes a nap on Isles of Scilly fishing boat
item.description: The walrus took to a local fishing boat for a spot of sunbathing in the Isles of Scilly.

item.title: Michelin-star restaurant stops serving lunch due to lack of staff
item.description: The founder of a Michelin-star restaurant says he had to reduce opening hours to manage shortages.

item.title: Covid sweeps India's Buddhist monasteries
item.description: Monasteries in India's Himalayan state of Sikkim have been especially vulnerable to Covid-19.

item.title: New York mayoral election: What voters want from a new mayor
item.description: Learn what's at stake as voters head to the polls to choose a new leader for New York City.

item.title: Love Island 2021: ITV announces cast with first disabled contestant
item.description: ITV’s biggest reality show returns for a seventh series with a brand-new cast of singletons.

item.title: Teachers' The Greatest Showman student TikTok dance goes viral
item.description: Their version of From Now On from the musical is watched more than 900,000 times in three weeks.

item.title: The Papers: Covid chaos at Euros, and blow to foreign holidays
item.description: The news that Scotland footballer Billy Gilmour has tested positive for Covid features on many front pages.

item.title: Summer solstice: Hundreds attend Stonehenge despite advice
item.description: Some scaled fences to enter the site in Wiltshire, with a live feed pulled amid safety concerns.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.

item.title: GP data sharing: What is it and can I opt out?
item.description: A scheme to centralise GP patient records in England has been delayed after concerns about a lack of publicity.

item.title: What is white privilege?
item.description: A new education report by a group of MPs has caused debate because of references to white privilege.

item.title: China fails to meet promises on missing Xinjiang children
item.description: China made a public pledge to help find Kalbinur Tursan's children but she may never see them again.

item.title: Eva Schloss: 'Why I took Austrian citizenship aged 92'
item.description: Eva Schloss has accepted Austrian citizenship, more than 80 years after she fled the country. Why?

item.title: Instagram model Demi Rose on why she joined OnlyFans
item.description: The model and influencer says she created an OnlyFans account to give her more career control.

item.title: India economy: Seven years of Modi in seven charts
item.description: Covid battered an already sluggish economy, weakened by poor growth, job losses and stagnant exports.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Does Japan have Covid under control?
item.description: With the Olympics starting in July, Covid cases are coming down from a peak in May.

item.title: How farmers and scientists are engineering your food
item.description: By manipulating genes scientists say they can create better-tasting produce, but is it necessary?

item.title: Covid vaccine: Why are Australians cancelling AstraZeneca jabs?
item.description: More people are shunning the world's most widely used Covid vaccine over its perceived risk.

item.title: World Test Championship final on knife-edge for sixth day
item.description: All results are possible in the final of the World Test Championship after an engrossing penultimate day between India and New Zealand.

item.title: Wembley to be allowed at least 60,000 fans for Euro 2020 semis and final
item.description: The crowd capacity at Wembley will be increased to more than 60,000 for the semi-finals and final of Euro 2020, says the UK government.

item.title: Mount and Chilwell absence 'bizarre', says England boss Southgate
item.description: England boss Gareth Southgate says the absence of Mason Mount and Ben Chilwell for the Euro 2020 game against the Czech Republic is a "bizarre situation full of contradictions".

item.title: Euro 2020: Raheem Sterling strike secures top spot for England
item.description: Watch highlights as a Raheem Sterling strike secures the top spot in Group D for England with a 1-0 win against the Czech Republic

item.title: Euro 2020: Scotland knocked out of Euros after Croatia defeat in Glasgow
item.description: Watch highlights as Luka Modric's superb strike ends Scotland's dream of making history by progressing at Euro 2020, with a heart-breaking 3-1 defeat by Croatia at Hampden.

item.title: Why are England players self-isolating but Scotland's not?
item.description: Two England players are self-isolating after a Scotland player tested positive for Covid.

item.title: Euro 2020: Rate the players - Croatia v Scotland
item.description: Rate the players in the Euro 2020 Group D match between Croatia and Scotland.

item.title: Euro 2020: Rate the players - Czech Republic v England
item.description: Rate the players in the Euro 2020 Group D match between Czech Republic and England.

item.title: Yes Sir, I Can Boogie: Why disco hit is now Scotland's unofficial anthem
item.description: The 1970s disco classic has become the country's unofficial anthem ahead of the match with England.

item.title: Harry Kane: Tracking England captain's evolution into world-class scoring machine
item.description: From sitting on the bench to becoming a scoring machine and the Premier League's best creator, we track Harry Kane's footballing evolution.

item.title: Euro 2020: fixtures, tables, last 16 news, permutations and TV listings
item.description: All you need to know from Euro 2020 with standings, results, remaining group fixtures and who awaits who in the last 16.

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Vaccine passports: How can I prove I've had both my Covid jabs?
item.description: People who've had both Covid jabs may soon be able to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over 40s in England and Scotland can have their second dose after eight weeks instead of 12.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: What are the care home visiting rules?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to people who want to go to see their loved ones.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Can we dance outside at our wedding? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Ros Atkins On… How the Delta variant took hold in the UK
item.description: Ros Atkins traces back the story of the Delta variant and how it delayed the UK’s reopening plans.

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions is being delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and receptions?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 42 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now available for younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?

item.title: Daniel Morgan: Last chance for family in Britain's most-investigated, unsolved murder
item.description: The death of Daniel Morgan is Britain's most investigated unsolved murder. His family believe police corruption, and reluctance to confront it, could explain the murder and the failed investigations

item.title: Troubled US teens left traumatised by tough love camps
item.description: Paris Hilton is among thousands who allege abuse at programmes aimed at reforming US teenagers.

item.title: Living with obesity: The people who are hard-wired to store fat
item.description: Specialist health professionals say obesity should be regarded as a complex illness, and people with the condition shouldn't be blamed for it.

item.title: Gary Allen: The killer who nearly got away with murder
item.description: Gary Allen's conviction for the murders of two women brings a 20-year quest for justice to an end.
